fields.name: Embrace The Madness
fields.composer: Jack Wall, Big Giant Circles, Uyanga Bold

fields.album: Call of Duty Black Ops II (Original Game Soundtrack)
Call of Duty®: Black Ops 7 (Original Soundtrack)
Call of Duty: Black Ops III (Official Soundtrack)
Call of Duty®: Black Ops 7 (Original Soundtrack)

fields.name: Alan Silvestri
fields.about: Alan Silvestri is a prolific American composer and conductor famous for iconic film scores like Back to the Future, Forrest Gump, The Avengers, Captain America and Predator, known for his energetic, melodic style and frequent collaborations with director Robert Zemeckis. He's a multi-award winner (Grammys, Emmys) with numerous Oscar and Golden Globe nominations, creating recognizable themes for over 100 films and TV shows.

fields.name: Brian Tyler
fields.about: Brian Tyler is a prolific American composer, conductor, and producer known for scoring blockbuster films (Fast & Furious, Avengers: Age of Ultron, Crazy Rich Asians), hit TV shows (Yellowstone, Hawaii Five-O), and video games, blending orchestral power with modern elements for massive franchises, even creating the Formula 1 theme and revamping the Universal Pictures logo. A versatile musician, he's an Academy inductee celebrated for his high-energy, globally successful scores, often conducting major orchestras for his work.

fields.name: Hans Zimmer
fields.about: Hans Zimmer is a world-renowned German film composer and producer, famous for his innovative fusion of electronic sounds with traditional orchestras, creating iconic scores for over 150 films like The Lion King, Gladiator, Inception, and Dune, winning multiple Oscars, Grammys, and Golden Globes for his work that defines cinematic emotion and scale. A self-taught musician and former band member, he became a Hollywood powerhouse by integrating new technology with classic scoring, leading the film music division at DreamWorks and influencing a generation of composers through his studio, Remote Control Productions.

fields.name: Jack Wall
fields.about: Jack Wall is a renowned American video game composer known for epic scores in franchises like Mass Effect, Call of Duty: Black Ops, and the Myst series, recognized for blending orchestral styles with deep storytelling, co-creating Video Games Live, and working with major artists before his game scoring career. He's an award-winning industry figure, co-founder of the Game Audio Network Guild (G.A.N.G.), and praised for his cinematic sound and innovative approach to game music.

fields.name: Lalo Schifrin
fields.about: Lalo Schifrin was an Argentine‑American composer, pianist, arranger, and conductor best known for creating the iconic 'Mission: Impossible' theme and scoring over 100 films and television shows, blending jazz, Latin American, and orchestral elements in classic works like Bullitt, Dirty Harry, Cool Hand Luke and more. Born in Buenos Aires, he studied at the Paris Conservatory and became a leading figure in film music, earning multiple Grammy Awards and an honorary Academy Award for his influential career. Schifrin passed away in 2025 at the age of 93.

fields.name: Danny Elfman
fields.about: Danny Elfman is an American composer, singer, songwriter and musician best known for his prolific film and television scoring career, creating iconic music for over 100 features including Pee‑wee’s Big Adventure, Batman, The Nightmare Before Christmas, Spider‑Man, and the main theme for The Simpsons. He began as the frontman of the new wave band Oingo Boingo before transitioning to film composition in the 1980s, frequently collaborating with director Tim Burton and earning acclaim for his distinctive, imaginative style. Elfman’s work has garnered multiple awards and nominations across Oscars, Emmys and Grammys. :contentReference[oaicite:0]{index=0}

fields.name: John Powell
fields.about: John Powell is an English film composer and conductor known for scoring over 70 feature films, including hit franchises such as the Bourne series, Happy Feet, X‑Men: The Last Stand, and How to Train Your Dragon. Based in Los Angeles since 1997, he has earned multiple Grammy nominations and Academy Award nominations for his dynamic and versatile film music, blending orchestral and rhythmic elements in both action and animated films. He was also part of Hans Zimmer’s Remote Control Productions and collaborated on many notable soundtracks.

fields.name: Lorne Balfe
fields.about: Lorne Balfe is a Scottish composer known for his work in film, television, and video game scores, including major franchises like Mission: Impossible, Top Gun: Maverick, Black Widow, Bad Boys for Life, and video games such as Assassin’s Creed and Call of Duty. A veteran of Hans Zimmer’s Remote Control Productions, he blends orchestral, electronic, and modern elements across genres and media, earning awards and nominations including Grammys, Emmys, and BAFTAs, with a career spanning from his early composing work in the late 1990s to major Hollywood projects.

fields.name: David Buckley
fields.about: David Buckley is a British Emmy‑nominated composer known for scoring films and television shows including The Town, Jason Bourne, The Nice Guys, Nobody, The Sandman, The Good Wife and The Good Fight. Born in London in 1976, he began his musical life in cathedral choirs, studied at Cambridge University, and later moved to Los Angeles to work with Harry Gregson‑Williams before establishing his own career composing dynamic orchestral and dramatic scores blending modern and traditional elements.

fields.name: Henry Jackman
fields.about: Henry Jackman is a British film and television music composer, conductor and arranger known for scoring major films including X‑Men: First Class, Captain America: The Winter Soldier, Captain America: Civil War, Kong: Skull Island, Puss in Boots and Monsters vs. Aliens, as well as video game soundtracks such as Uncharted 4: A Thief’s End and Battlefield 6. Born in London in 1974, he studied classical music and began working in the industry in the early 1990s, later collaborating with Hans Zimmer before becoming a leading composer in Hollywood for his dynamic and versatile scores.

fields.name: James Newton Howard
fields.about: James Newton Howard is an American film composer, orchestrator and music producer known for scoring over 100 films including Pretty Woman, The Fugitive, The Sixth Sense, Batman Begins (with Hans Zimmer), the Fantastic Beasts and The Hunger Games franchises. Born in Los Angeles, he began his musical career in the 1970s as a keyboardist touring with artists like Elton John and Toto before transitioning to film scoring in the mid‑1980s and becoming one of Hollywood’s most respected composers, earning multiple Grammy and Emmy wins and numerous Oscar nominations.

fields.name: Nino Rota
fields.about: Nino Rota was an Italian composer best known for his prolific and influential film scores, including long collaborations with director Federico Fellini on films like La Strada, La Dolce Vita, and 8½, as well as the iconic music for Francis Ford Coppola’s The Godfather and The Godfather Part II. Born in Milan, he was a musical prodigy who composed from an early age, studied in Italy and the United States, and went on to compose more than 150 film scores alongside operas, ballets, and orchestral works, becoming one of the most important figures in 20th‑century cinema music. Rota died in Rome in 1979.

fields.name: Junkie XL
fields.about: Junkie XL (Tom Holkenborg) is a Dutch composer, electronic music producer, multi‑instrumentalist, DJ and film scorer known for his transition from electronic and big beat albums in the 1990s to major Hollywood film scores including Mad Max: Fury Road, Deadpool, Sonic the Hedgehog and Justice League, blending electronic, orchestral and experimental elements. Born in Lichtenvoorde, Netherlands on December 8, 1967, he began performing and producing music in the late 1980s and released his first album under the Junkie XL name in 1997, later becoming a notable film composer working with major directors and studios.

fields.name: Charlie Clouser
fields.about: Charlie Clouser is an American musician, composer, record producer, and remixer known for his work scoring the Saw film franchise and television series like Las Vegas and NUMB3RS. He was born in Hanover, New Hampshire, and played keyboards and programming with the industrial rock band Nine Inch Nails from 1994 to 2000 before establishing his career composing film and TV music. Clouser has also remixed major artists and collaborated across music and media.

fields.name: Tyler Bates
fields.about: Tyler Bates is an American film and media composer and music producer known for his dynamic scores on films such as 300, Dawn of the Dead, Guardians of the Galaxy, John Wick, Watchmen, Sucker Punch, and Rob Zombie’s horror movies. Born on June 5, 1965 in Los Angeles, he began his professional composing career in the early 1990s scoring low‑budget films and went on to become a prominent composer in Hollywood, blending orchestral and modern elements across genres.

fields.name: Le Castle Vania
fields.about: Le Castle Vania is the stage name of American electronic music producer, DJ, and composer Dylan Eiland, known for his energetic electronic dance music, remixes, and original contributions to film soundtracks including the John Wick series. He began his career as a DJ and producer in the mid‑2000s with the release of his remix of Snowden’s “Black Eyes,” and has since become a prominent figure in electronic music and media scoring.

fields.name: Chris Benstead
fields.about: Chris Benstead is a British film composer, arranger and Academy Award‑winning re‑recording mixer known for scoring films and television including The Gentlemen, Wrath of Man, Operation Fortune: Ruse de Guerre, The Covenant and The Ministry of Ungentlemanly Warfare. He began his music career working as a music editor and mixer on major films before transitioning into full composition work with his first score for the Guy Ritchie film The Gentlemen in 2019, blending orchestral and modern cinematic elements.

fields.name: A. R. Rahman
fields.about: A. R. Rahman is an acclaimed Indian composer, singer‑songwriter and music producer known for revolutionizing Indian film music with his work on Roja, Bombay, Lagaan, Slumdog Millionaire and more, blending classical, electronic and world music. Born Allah Rakha Rahman (originally A. S. Dileep Kumar) on January 6, 1967 in Madras (now Chennai), India, he began his professional career by composing jingles before his breakthrough film score for Mani Ratnam’s Roja in 1992, which launched him to national and international fame with numerous awards including Oscars, Grammys, a Golden Globe and a BAFTA.

fields.name: M83
fields.about: M83 is a French electronic music project formed in Antibes, France, by Anthony Gonzalez and Nicolas Fromageau, known for blending shoegaze, synth‑pop, ambient and electronic rock in critically acclaimed albums and soundtracks including ‘‘Hurry Up, We're Dreaming’’ and the hit ‘‘Midnight City’’. Formed as a duo, Gonzalez remains the primary creative force while M83’s music has garnered international success and influence since the early 2000s.

fields.name: Walter Mair
fields.about: Walter Mair is an Austrian‑born composer known for scoring films, television, video games and documentaries with a blend of orchestral and electronic music. His work includes music for titles such as Till Death, Liaison, Call of Duty: Modern Warfare III and Squid Game, and he has received Ivor Novello and Telly Award recognition for his compositions. Born on December 17, 1978 in Vienna, he studied music composition and has worked internationally, establishing his studio in London and contributing to notable multimedia projects.

fields.name: Sarah Schachner
fields.about: Sarah Schachner is an American composer and musician known for scoring music for major video games and films, including Assassin’s Creed Unity, Assassin’s Creed Origins, Anthem, Call of Duty: Infinite Warfare, Call of Duty: Modern Warfare II, and films like The Lazarus Effect and Prey. She began working in the industry composing additional music on major projects before earning full scoring roles and has been recognized for her dynamic blend of orchestral and electronic elements in game and media scores.

fields.name: Ennio Morricone
fields.about: Ennio Morricone was an Italian composer, orchestrator and conductor renowned for his prolific work in film and television, composing over 500 scores including iconic Spaghetti Westerns such as The Good, the Bad and the Ugly, Once Upon a Time in the West, and films like Cinema Paradiso, The Mission, and The Untouchables. Born on November 10, 1928 in Rome, Italy, he began his professional career in the early 1950s composing for radio and film, becoming one of the most influential film composers in cinematic history with numerous awards including Oscars, Golden Globes, and BAFTAs.

fields.name: Vince DiCola
fields.about: Vince DiCola is an American composer, keyboardist and arranger known for his work on iconic 1980s film scores including Staying Alive, Rocky IV and The Transformers: The Movie. Born in Lancaster, Pennsylvania, he moved to California in 1981, where he began his professional music career as a session musician and composer. DiCola’s early breakthrough came when he co‑wrote songs for the Staying Alive soundtrack, launching him into film composition and synthesizer‑driven scoring.

fields.name: Toma Otowa
fields.about: Toma Otowa is a Japanese film and video game composer based in Los Angeles known for contributing music to major Hollywood films such as Thor: Ragnarok, Croods: A New Age, The Lego Movie 2 and Hotel Transylvania 3, as well as video game titles like Resident Evil 5, Afrika, Halo 2 Anniversary and Ratchet & Clank: Rift Apart. Born in Aizuwakamatsu, Fukushima, Japan on August 24, 1974, he has built a diverse career blending orchestral and media scoring across global projects.

fields.name: Ilan Eshkeri
fields.about: Ilan Eshkeri is a British composer known for his work on film, television, and video game music, including scores for Layer Cake, Stardust, The Young Victoria, Still Alice, Ghost of Tsushima, and Shaun the Sheep Movie. Born on April 7, 1977 in London, he studied music and English literature at the University of Leeds and began his professional composing career with his first major credited film score for the crime film Layer Cake in 2004, gaining recognition in the industry for his evocative and diverse musical style.

fields.name: Himesh Reshammiya
fields.about: Himesh Reshammiya is an Indian music composer, singer, songwriter and actor known for his prolific work in Bollywood film music since the late 1990s. He made his debut as a music composer contributing songs to the 1998 Salman Khan film Pyaar Kiya To Darna Kya, and went on to gain prominence with hit soundtracks for films such as Tere Naam, Aashiq Banaya Aapne and numerous others, later establishing himself as a singer and actor in Indian cinema.

fields.name: Rob Dougan
fields.about: Rob Dougan is an Australian composer, producer and musician known for blending orchestral arrangements with electronic and trip hop elements, gaining widespread recognition for his 1995 breakthrough single “Clubbed to Death (Kurayamino Variation)” which was later featured on The Matrix soundtrack. Born in 1969 in Sydney, he began his professional music career in the early 1990s as a DJ and remix artist and went on to release his debut album Furious Angels and contribute music that bridged electronic and cinematic styles.

fields.name: Michael Giacchino
fields.about: Michael Giacchino is an American composer known for scoring some of the most acclaimed films and television series of the 21st century, including The Incredibles, Ratatouille, Up, Lost, Star Trek, Jurassic World, Rogue One: A Star Wars Story, Spider‑Man films, Doctor Strange, and many more. Born on October 10, 1967 in Riverside, New Jersey, he began his professional music career composing for video games and television before his first major feature film score for The Incredibles, which premiered in 2004, launching his Hollywood career.

fields.name: Ludwig Göransson
fields.about: Ludwig Göransson is a Swedish composer, conductor and record producer known for his work scoring film, television and media, including the sitcom Community, the Disney+ Star Wars series The Mandalorian, and major films like Tenet, Fruitvale Station, Creed, Black Panther and Oppenheimer. Born on September 1, 1984 in Linköping, Sweden, he began his professional composing career with his first credited work on the NBC series Community in 2009, later winning multiple Academy Awards and Emmy Awards for his dynamic and innovative music.

fields.name: Big Giant Circles
fields.about: Big Giant Circles is the stage name of American composer and electronic musician Jimmy Hinson, known for his video game music compositions and electronic work in titles such as Borderlands 2, Threes!, There Came an Echo, Super Street Fighter II Turbo HD Remix and Mass Effect 2. Born on July 27, 1981, in the United States, he started his career composing and remixing video game music in the early 2000s with contributions on OverClocked ReMix before releasing his debut independent album Impostor Nostalgia in 2011 and becoming an active professional composer in the games industry.

fields.name: Adrián Berenguer
fields.about: Adrián Berenguer is a Spanish composer and musician from Alicante who creates music for films, video games and instrumental albums. Born March 11, 1988, he began his professional composing career with projects such as Timothy vs. The Aliens and Effie, later scoring works like Summer in Mara, Koa and the Five Pirates of Mara and numerous solo instrumental albums under his ANBR alias, blending cinematic, orchestral and modern electronic elements across media.

fields.name: Ramin Djawadi
fields.about: Ramin Djawadi is a German‑Iranian composer and music producer known for scoring major films and television series including Iron Man, Pacific Rim, Prison Break, Person of Interest, Westworld, and Game of Thrones. Born on July 19, 1974 in Duisburg, Germany, he moved to the United States to study at Berklee College of Music and began his professional music career assisting Hans Zimmer before his first solo credited score for the television series Angel in 2001, establishing him as a prominent composer in Hollywood.

fields.name: Trevor Jones
fields.about: Trevor Jones is a South African-born composer known for scoring numerous films including The Last of the Mohicans, Labyrinth, Mississippi Burning, Excalibur, and The Dark Crystal. Born on March 15, 1949 in Cape Town, South Africa, he moved to London to study music and began his professional composing career with his first credited film score for the 1974 film The Awakening, establishing him as a significant figure in cinematic music.

fields.name: Randy Edelman
fields.about: Randy Edelman is an American composer and conductor known for scoring films such as Dragon: The Bruce Lee Story, Gettysburg, Dragonheart, The Mask, Kindergarten Cop, and Tombstone. Born on June 10, 1947 in Paterson, New Jersey, he began his professional composing career in the early 1970s, with his first credited film score for the movie Sweet Kill in 1973, establishing his presence in Hollywood as a versatile composer blending orchestral and contemporary styles.

fields.name: Jerry Goldsmith
fields.about: Jerry Goldsmith was an American composer and conductor known for his prolific work in film and television, including scores for Planet of the Apes, Patton, Chinatown, Star Trek: The Motion Picture, The Omen, Total Recall, Basic Instinct and Rambo Series. Born on February 10, 1929 in Los Angeles, California, he began his professional composing career in 1951 with his first credited film score for City Across the River, establishing him as one of Hollywood’s most influential and versatile composers.

fields.name: Sean Murray
fields.about: Sean Murray is an American composer known for his work in television, film, and video games, including scoring music for NCIS, The Land Before Time film series, and various other projects. Born on June 27, 1965, in the United States, he began his professional composing career in the late 1980s, with his first credited work for the TV movie Christmas Comes to Willow Creek in 1987, establishing him as a notable composer in media.

fields.name: James Horner
fields.about: James Horner was an American composer and conductor known for his prolific work in film music, including iconic scores for Titanic, Avatar, Braveheart, Field of Dreams, Apollo 13, Glory, and Star Trek II: The Wrath of Khan. Born on August 14, 1953, in Los Angeles, California, he studied at the Royal College of Music and UCLA, and began his professional composing career with his first credited film score for the 1978 movie The Lady in Red, establishing himself as one of Hollywood's most influential composers.

fields.name: Joel J. Richard
fields.about: Joel J. Richard is an American composer known for co‑scoring the John Wick film franchise alongside Tyler Bates, including John Wick (2014), Chapter 2, Chapter 3 – Parabellum, and John Wick: Chapter 4, as well as contributing music for television series such as Quantico. He began his career working in the music department with prominent composers and transitioned into major film composition work, helping shape the distinctive hybrid sound of the John Wick scores.

fields.name: Lucky Ali
fields.about: Lucky Ali is an Indian singer, composer, songwriter, and actor known for his soulful voice and pop music contributions in the Indian music industry. Born Maqsood Ali on September 19, 1958, he began his professional music career with his debut album *Sunoh*, released in 1996, which gained critical and commercial acclaim and established him as a prominent figure in Indian pop music.

fields.name: Michael Jackson
fields.about: Michael Jackson was an American singer, songwriter, and dancer, widely regarded as the King of Pop. Born on August 29, 1958, in Gary, Indiana, he began his professional music career as the lead singer of the Jackson 5, releasing their first single 'I Want You Back' in 1969. He later became a global solo superstar with albums like Off the Wall, Thriller, and Bad, revolutionizing pop music, dance, and music videos.

fields.name: Vangelis
fields.about: Vangelis, born Evangelos Odysseas Papathanassiou, was a Greek composer and electronic music pioneer known for his atmospheric and innovative film scores including Chariots of Fire, Blade Runner, 1492: Conquest of Paradise, and Antarctica. Born on March 29, 1943, in Volos, Greece, he began his professional music career in the early 1960s with the Greek band Forminx, and later moved into electronic music and film scoring, becoming a globally influential composer.

fields.name: Mark Mancina
fields.about: Mark Mancina is an American composer known for his work on film scores such as Speed, Twister, Tarzan, Moana, Bad Boys II, and training wheels for video games and TV. Born on March 25, 1956, in Los Angeles, California, he began his professional composing career in the 1980s, with his first major credited film score for the 1987 film Warning Sign, establishing him as a prominent figure in cinematic music.

fields.name: David Arnold
fields.about: David Arnold is a British composer known for scoring major films and television series including Independence Day, Stargate, Godzilla, multiple James Bond films (Tomorrow Never Dies, The World Is Not Enough, Die Another Day, Casino Royale, Quantum of Solace) and Sherlock. Born on January 23, 1962, in Luton, England, he began his professional composing career with his first credited film score for the 1989 movie Licence to Kill, establishing him as a prominent composer in cinematic music.

fields.name: Kitaro
fields.about: Kitaro, born Masanori Takahashi, is a Japanese composer, musician, and multi-instrumentalist known for his pioneering work in new-age and electronic music, blending traditional Japanese instruments with synthesizers and global influences. Born on February 4, 1953, in Toyohashi, Japan, he began his professional music career in the early 1970s as a member of the folk band Far East Family Band before releasing his first solo album, Ten Kai, in 1978, establishing his solo career as a prominent figure in new-age music.

fields.name: Steve Jablonsky
fields.about: Steve Jablonsky is an American composer known for scoring blockbuster films and video games, including the Transformers series, Battleship, Lone Survivor, and video game titles such as Gears of War. Born on October 9, 1970, in Los Angeles, California, he began his professional composing career working as a music assistant to Hans Zimmer before receiving his first solo credited film score for the movie The Texas Chainsaw Massacre in 2003, establishing his career as a prominent Hollywood composer.

fields.name: David Garrett
fields.about: David Garrett is a German classical and crossover violinist known for blending classical music with rock and pop influences. Born on September 4, 1980, in Aachen, Germany, he began his professional music career at a young age, performing with major orchestras and releasing his first solo album, David Garrett, in 1997, establishing him as a prominent violinist internationally.

fields.name: Michael Price
fields.about: Michael Price is a British composer, arranger and music editor known for scoring numerous film and television projects including Sherlock (with David Arnold), Unforgotten, Eternal Beauty, Wild Child and others, as well as his work editing and contributing to major scores such as The Lord of the Rings trilogy and Band of Brothers. His first film work came when he was invited by composer Michael Kamen to orchestrate and program sounds for Event Horizon (1997), launching his professional career in cinematic music.

fields.name: Enigma
fields.about: Enigma is a musical project founded by German producer and composer Michael Cretu, known for blending electronic, new-age, and world music elements. Enigma gained worldwide fame with the 1990 release of their debut album *MCMXC a.D.*, featuring the hit single 'Sadeness (Part I)', which introduced a distinctive fusion of Gregorian chants, ambient sounds, and electronic beats.

fields.name: Moby
fields.about: Moby, born Richard Melville Hall, is an American musician, songwriter, singer, producer, and DJ known for pioneering electronic music and blending techno, house, ambient, and rock influences. Born on September 11, 1965, in New York City, he began his professional music career in the late 1980s, releasing his debut album *Moby* in 1992, which marked the start of his globally recognized career in electronic music.

fields.name: Chris Cornell
fields.about: Chris Cornell was an American singer, songwriter, and musician, best known as the lead vocalist for Soundgarden and Audioslave, and for his solo work. Born on July 20, 1964, in Seattle, Washington, he began his professional music career in 1984 when Soundgarden released their debut EP *Screaming Life*, marking the start of his influential role in the grunge and rock music scene.

fields.name: Daniel Pemberton
fields.about: Daniel Pemberton is a British composer known for scoring films such as The Awakening, The Counselor, Steve Jobs, The Man from U.N.C.L.E., Molly’s Game, Spider‑Man: Into the Spider‑Verse, and The Trial of the Chicago 7, blending orchestral, electronic, and innovative styles. Born on November 3, 1977, in the United Kingdom, he began his professional film composing career with his debut score for The Awakening in 2011 before going on to collaborate with major directors and earn multiple award nominations.

fields.name: Bill Conti
fields.about: Bill Conti is an American composer and conductor known for his work on film scores such as Rocky, The Right Stuff, For Your Eyes Only, and television themes including Dynasty. Born on April 13, 1942, in Providence, Rhode Island, he began his professional composing career with his first credited film score for the movie The Baltimore Bullet in 1980, marking the start of his prolific career in Hollywood.

fields.name: Marco Beltrami
fields.about: Marco Beltrami is an American composer known for his work on film scores including Scream, Resident Evil, 3:10 to Yuma, The Wolverine, A Quiet Place, and many other horror and action films. Born on October 7, 1966, in New York City, he began his professional composing career with his first credited film score for the 1992 movie A Bottle in the Gaza Strip, establishing his presence in cinematic music.

fields.name: Brad Fiedel
fields.about: Brad Fiedel is an American composer and musician best known for his electronic and synthesizer-based film scores, including The Terminator, Terminator 2: Judgment Day, and True Lies, as well as work on many other films and television projects. Born on May 10, 1951, he began his professional composing career with his first credited film score for the 1979 movie Fade to Black, establishing himself as an innovative composer in Hollywood.

fields.name: Daft Punk
fields.about: Daft Punk was a French electronic music duo formed by Thomas Bangalter and Guy-Manuel de Homem-Christo, known for pioneering house, electronic, and dance music with albums like Homework, Discovery, Human After All, and Random Access Memories. They gained global recognition for their innovative sound, visual identity, and live performances.

fields.name: Giorgio Moroder
fields.about: Giorgio Moroder is an Italian composer, songwriter, and record producer, widely regarded as a pioneer of electronic disco and synth music. Born on April 26, 1940, in Ortisei, Italy, he began his professional music career in the mid-1960s, releasing his first single and later producing groundbreaking albums and film scores, including hits for Donna Summer and soundtracks for films like Midnight Express, Scarface, and Top Gun.

fields.name: Jim Johnston
fields.about: Jim Johnston is an American composer and music producer best known for creating entrance theme music for professional wrestlers in WWE for over three decades. Born on February 19, 1952, he began his professional music career with WWE (then WWF) in 1985, composing and producing iconic themes such as The Undertaker, Stone Cold Steve Austin, and The Rock, significantly influencing the sound of sports entertainment.

fields.name: Kenji Kawai
fields.about: Kenji Kawai is a Japanese composer and music producer known for scoring anime, film, and video games, including Ghost in the Shell, Mobile Suit Gundam, Ring, and Patlabor. Born on April 23, 1957, in Shinagawa, Tokyo, Japan, he began his professional composing career in 1983 with his first credited film score for the movie The Water Was So Clear, establishing himself as a prominent figure in Japanese cinematic and electronic music.

fields.name: Lisa Gerrard
fields.about: Lisa Gerrard is an Australian musician, singer, and composer best known for her work as one‑half of the influential music duo Dead Can Dance and for her acclaimed contributions to film scores. She is noted for her distinctive vocal style and range, often singing in a self‑created language, and her blending of world music, neoclassical, and ambient elements. Gerrard has won a Golden Globe Award for Best Original Score for Gladiator (with Hans Zimmer) and has contributed to many other films, including The Insider, Whale Rider, and Balibo. Her professional career began with the formation of Dead Can Dance in 1981, leading to both group and solo success in music and cinema.

fields.name: Zack Hemsey
fields.about: Zack Hemsey is an American composer, musician, songwriter, and filmmaker known for his cinematic and emotionally powerful music that blends orchestral, electronic, hip‑hop, and alternative elements. His compositions have been widely used in film trailers and visual media, most notably the track “Mind Heist,” featured in the trailer for *Inception* (2010). Hemsey began his musical career in the hip‑hop collective Nine Leaves before launching a solo career with the release of his first album, *Empty Room*, in 2010. Since then, he has independently released several albums and his work has appeared in trailers and films such as *The Equalizer* and *Game of Thrones* promotional material.

fields.name: John Paesano
fields.about: John Paesano is an American composer, conductor, arranger, and music producer known for his work in film, television, and video games. He has composed scores for major franchises and projects, including the Maze Runner film series, Marvel’s Daredevil and The Defenders, the Detroit: Become Human video game, and multiple Marvel’s Spider‑Man video games. Paesano’s music blends orchestral and electronic elements to enhance narrative and emotional depth, and his work has earned him awards such as the BAFTA Games Award for music. He began his professional career contributing additional music in 1997 before scoring his own film and game projects.

fields.name: Cheetah Mobile
fields.about: Cheetah Mobile is a Chinese mobile internet company that also releases music tracks and original soundtracks for its mobile games, such as the *Rolling Sky* game series. In music credits, "Cheetah Mobile" appears as the composer/artist name for many electronic and soundtrack songs associated with its game releases, with original soundtrack albums released under the Cheetah Mobile name. These compositions are typically credited to the company rather than a single individual composer, and are part of the musical branding for its games and apps.

fields.name: Ajurika
fields.about: Ajurika is the professional alias of Japanese composer Akitaka Tohyama, a music producer, composer, arranger, and DJ best known for his work on popular video game soundtracks. He composed music for major titles at Bandai Namco such as TEKKEN, Ridge Racer, Katamari Damacy, Urban Reign, and titles in THE iDOLM@STER series, contributing to game music and original tracks. After working at Bandai Namco from 1997 to 2013, he became a freelance composer and continues to release music and produce compositions under the name Ajurika.

fields.name: Thomas Newman
fields.about: Thomas Newman is an American composer and conductor renowned for his film scores, blending orchestral and electronic elements with distinctive textures. He comes from a renowned family of film composers and has created music for numerous acclaimed films and television series. His professional career as a film composer began with his first full feature score for the romantic drama "Reckless" (1984), marking his entry into film scoring.

fields.name: The Newton Brothers
fields.about: The Newton Brothers are an American film and television composing duo consisting of Andy Grush and Taylor Newton Stewart, known for their atmospheric and eclectic scores in genre films and series. They have composed music for over a decade on projects including *Detachment*, *Oculus*, *The Haunting of Hill House*, *Midnight Mass*, *X‑Men ’97*, and *Daredevil: Born Again*, blending orchestral and electronic elements to enhance narrative and emotion. Their professional partnership as “The Newton Brothers” began in the early 2010s, and they have since become frequent collaborators with directors such as Mike Flanagan. :contentReference[oaicite:0]{index=0}

fields.name: Justin Hurwitz
fields.about: Justin Hurwitz is an American film composer known for his acclaimed collaborations with director Damien Chazelle, scoring films such as *Guy and Madeline on a Park Bench* (2009), *Whiplash* (2014), *La La Land* (2016), *First Man* (2018), and *Babylon* (2022). His work has earned multiple Academy Awards, Golden Globes, Grammys, and BAFTA awards, blending orchestral and modern elements to create emotive and memorable film scores. Hurwitz began his professional composing career with his first full feature film score on *Guy and Madeline on a Park Bench*.

fields.name: Nick Arundel
fields.about: Nick Arundel is an English video game composer and audio director known for his atmospheric and emotive scores on major video game titles, including *I‑Ninja* and the *Batman: Arkham* series. He blends orchestral and electronic elements to enhance the narrative depth and mood in interactive media, working on projects for studios such as Rocksteady and Warner Bros. Arundel has also served as audio director on later installments in the Batman franchise and continues to compose music for games.

fields.name: Joe Kraemer
fields.about: Joe Kraemer is an American film and television composer known for his dynamic and narrative‑driven scores. He has worked on numerous films, including Christopher McQuarrie’s *The Way of the Gun* (2000), *Jack Reacher* (2012), and *Mission: Impossible – Rogue Nation* (2015), blending orchestral and thematic elements to enhance storytelling. Kraemer’s professional career in feature film composing began with his first full score for *The Way of the Gun*, marking his entry into the industry after earlier work on short films and roles as a music editor and sound designer.

fields.name: Harold Faltermeyer
fields.about: Harold Faltermeyer is a German musician, composer, keyboardist, and record producer best known for his influential synth‑driven film scores in the 1980s and beyond. He gained international recognition for composing iconic themes such as “Axel F” from *Beverly Hills Cop* and the “Top Gun Anthem” for *Top Gun*, helping define the sound of electronic film music during that era. Before his success as a composer, he worked as an arranger, session musician, and producer, collaborating with artists like Donna Summer and Pet Shop Boys. Over his long career he has blended electronic and orchestral elements and has continued composing for film, television, and other media.

fields.name: Brian Tuey
fields.about: Brian Tuey is an American sound designer, composer, and audio director best known for his work on the *Call of Duty* video game series, especially the Zombies mode. He has composed original tracks and served in audio director roles on multiple titles, collaborating with other composers such as Kevin Sherwood and James McCawley. Tuey’s music contributions include writing and arranging music for many *Call of Duty* Zombies maps and soundtracks, blending interactive and cinematic audio elements in game scoring.

fields.name: Geek Music
fields.about: Geek Music is a UK‑based independent music production house and label specializing in cover versions, re‑recordings, and original arrangements of movie, television, video game, and anime themes. They release music across digital platforms and offer services including composing, orchestrating, and sync licensing. Geek Music has amassed a large catalogue of soundtrack‑style covers and has grown a substantial streaming audience worldwide. Their work blends orchestral and electronic influences adapted from iconic themes.

fields.name: Elliot Goldenthal
fields.about: Elliot Goldenthal is an American composer known for his work in film, theater, opera, and contemporary classical music, blending orchestral, avant‑garde, and experimental styles. He has composed more than 30 film scores, including *Drugstore Cowboy*, *Alien³*, *Interview with the Vampire*, *Michael Collins*, *Batman Forever*, *Heat*, and *Frida*, the latter earning him an Academy Award for Best Original Score. Goldenthal studied composition with Aaron Copland and John Corigliano and has also written music for ballet and opera alongside his film work.

fields.object_repr: Details for Afghanistan 2025 + Album Call of Duty Black Ops II (Original Game Soundtrack)
